Advanced presentation of concepts in endocrinology with emphasis on the role
of hormones in reproduction, metabolism, and disease.

name: Ordinary Diff Equations
First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: ICA Sports Program
description:
Sport specific advanced comprehensive training, instruction, and practice for
the highly skilled collegiate varsity athlete. Development and improvement of
performance skills utilizing motor-learning, nutritional science, and
motivational theory. Classes offered in all UC Davis intercollegiate athletic
sports.

name: Voice
description: Individual instruction in voice.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Directed Gp Study
description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Animal-Plant Interaction
description:
Animal adaptations for eating plants, pollinating flowers, dispersing seeds.
Plant adaptations to herbivore defense, attraction of mutualists; role of
coevolutionary arms race, mutualists and cheaters in plant/animal speciation.
Exploration through lectures, original scientific literature, discussions and
term paper.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Elementary Accounting
description:
Basic concepts of accounting; interpreting and using financial statements;
understanding accounting principles.

name: Intermed Japanese
description:
Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Japanese in cultural
context, based on language skills developed in JPN 003.
prereq: JPN 003 C- or better; Or the equivalent language proficiency.

name: Differential Equations
description: Solutions of elementary differential equations.
prereq: (MAT 022A C- or better or MAT 067 C- or better)

name: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Cultural Div Ed Sociopol
description:
Introduction to cultural diversity and education in a sociopolitical context.
Interactive course. Small and large-group discussions explore, extend, and
apply readings; range of writing genres for responses to assignments and
course themes; lectures, slide shows, speakers, brief fieldwork, and
presentations.

name: University Symphony
description:
Open to any student in the University whose proficiency meets the requirements
of concert performance. Sight-reading, rehearsal and performance of music from
the orchestral literature.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Intro to the University
description:
Introduction to resources supporting first year student academic success and
transition to a tier one research university.
prereq:
Consent of Instructor. Student must be a part of an approved Foundations for
University Success program.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Enzymes & Receptors
description:
Introduction to the principles of enzyme kinetics and receptor-ligand
interactions with emphasis on metabolic regulation and data analysis. Topics
include simultaneous equilibria, chemical and steady-state kinetics,
allosteric enzymes, mulitreactant systems, enzyme assays, membrane transport
and computer-assisted simulations and analyses.

name: Intro to Schools
Directed Gp Study
description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

name: Fluid Mechanics
description:
Fluid properties, fluid statics, continuity and linear momentum equations for
control volumes, flow of incompressible fluids in pipes, dimensional analysis
and boundary-layer flows.
prereq: ENG 035 C- or better; MAT 022B C- or better; PHY 009B C- or better

name: Food, Folklore, & Health
description:
Ancient and modern food folklore in relation to health and well-being. Food
safety, organic food, herbalism, food preservation, and nutritional
enhancement.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Topics In Na Lit
description: Special topics drawn from Native American literature.
prereq:
Upper division standing and one of the following recommended: NAS 005, NAS
010, NAS 181A, NAS 181C.

name: Philos Logic & Math
description:
Nature of formal systems and mathematical theories. Selected topics include
logical and semantical paradoxes; foundations of mathematics; set theory, type
theory, and intuitionistic theory; philosophy of geometry; philosophical
implications of Gdels incompleteness results.
prereq: PHI 012; Or one course for credit in mathematics.

name: Elementary Hebrew
description:
Speaking, listening, comprehension, reading and writing fundamentals of modern
Hebrew.

name: Western Civ
description: Growth of western civilization from late antiquity to the Renaissance.

name: Hydraulics Lab
description:
Laboratory experiments and demonstrations on flow measurements, sluice gates,
hydraulic jump, flow characteristics, and centrifugal pumps.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Intro to Bioethics
description:
Critical analysis of normative issues raised by contemporary medicine and
biology. Possible topics include euthanasia, reproductive technologies,
genetic engineering, informed consent and patient autonomy, experimentation on
human subjects and non-human animals.

name: East Asian Civ
description:
Surveys traditional Japanese civilization and its modern transformation.
Emphasis is on thought and religion, political and social life, art and
literature. Perspectives on contemporary Japan are provided.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Latin Amer Culture & His
description:
Introduce to the cultural and intellectual history of modern Latin America
including architecture, cinema, painting, music and literature.

name: Evol & Paleo of Dinosaur
description:
Introduction to evolutionary biology, paleobiology, ecology and paleoecology,
using dinosaurs as case studies.

name: Circuits I
description:
Basic electric circuit analysis techniques, including electrical quantities
and elements, resistive circuits, transient and steady-state responses of RLC
circuits, sinusoidal excitation and phasors, and complex frequency and network
functions.

name: German Women & Film
description:
Knowledge of German not required. Women in German film from the Weimar
Republic to present, with special emphasis on conceptualizations of gender,
historical and political context, aesthetic and filmic innovations.

name: Software Engineering
description:
Requirements, specification, design, implementation, testing, and verification
of large software systems. Study and use of software engineering
methodologies. Team programming.

name: Bayanihan Clinic
description:
Through active participation in the medical aspects of community health
clinics, the undergraduate student gains knowledge of the organization,
administration, and problem-solving capabilities.

name: Intermediate Theory
description:
Homophonic music of the Classical era with a focus on analysis of music by
Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven. Composition of pieces in the homophonic forms
such as minuet and trio, theme and variations, rondo and sonata. Intended for
music majors.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Production Lab
description: Laboratory experience in quantity food production and service.

name: American Lit 1900-1945
description:
Historically or thematically focused study of American literature (drama,
poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1900 and the end of World War
II.
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; Or the equivalent.

name: Africa to 1900
description:
Introduction to African history to 1900. Origins and impact of early human
history, precolonial states and societies, slavery and the slave trade,
religious and cultural movements, and the foundations of European colonialism.

name: Signals & Systems II
description:
Characterization and analysis of discrete time systems. Difference equation
models. Ztransform analysis methods. Discrete and fast Fourier transforms.
Introduction to digital filter design.

name: Intro Topics in Lit
description:
Study of a special topic. Literature written in English in any period or place
or genre. Thematic, formal, or temporal focus.
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; Or equivalent.

name: Iran & Persian Studies
description:
Iran & Persian topics for students specializing in region-specific Middle East
& South Asia Studies.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Lit in English I
description:
Historical introduction to English language and literature from 800-1700.
Linguistic borrowing, innovation, and change. Emergence of key literary
genres. Colonial America as a new site of English literary production and
consumption.
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; Or equivalent.

name: New Italian Cinema
description:
Italian cinema of the 21st century in the context of profound cultural and
social changes in Italy since World War II. Productions by representative
directors such as Amelio, Giordana, Moretti, Muccino are included. Knowledge
of Italian not required. May be taught abroad.
prereq: FMS 001; and upper division standing, or consent of instructor.

name: German Writing Skills
description:
Practice in different kinds of writing, such as abstracts, correspondence,
lecture summaries, analysis of or response to short literary texts.

name: Intermediate German
description:
Review of grammatical principles by means of written exercises; expanding of
vocabulary through readings of modern texts.
prereq: GER 003; can be concurrent with GER 006.

name: Intro to Army Leadership
description:
United States Army, its organization, customs, courtesies, and rank structure.
Surveys personal development skills needed for effective leadership such as
critical thinking, time management, and health and fitness. Familiarization
with the Army ROTC program.

name: Food Processing
description:
Application of the conservation of mass and energy to food processing.
Elements of engineering thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, heat and mass
transfer. Quantitative analysis through problem solving and simulation.
prereq:
PHY 007A; PHY 007B; PHY 007C { can be concurrent }; (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or
MAT 021C)

name: Elementary Japanese
description:
Introduction to spoken and written Japanese in cultural contexts, with
emphasis on communication.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Mod Europe To 1815
description:
Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion,
research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history.
Modern Europe to 1815.

name: Global Disease Biol Sem
description:
Seminar leading to development of the research proposal and academic plan for
the Global Disease Biology major.

name: Princ Of Macroecon
description:
ECN 001A & ECN 001B may be taken in either order. Analysis of the economy as a
whole; determinants of the level of income, employment and prices; money and
banking, economic fluctuations, international trade, economic development; the
role of public policy.

name: Intl Microeconomics
description:
International grade theory: impact of trade on the domestic and world
economies; public policy toward external trade.
prereq: ECN 100 or (ARE 100A, ARE 100B); or Consent of Instructor.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Genes Nutrients Health
description:
Biochemical, physiological, genetic, and nutritional causes of important
medical problems such as obesity, anorexia, heart disease and diabetes.
prereq: BIS 001A or BIS 002A; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Radiation & Antennas
description:
Properties of electromagnetic radiation; analysis and design of antennas:
ideal cylindrical, small loop, aperture, and arrays; antenna field
measurements.

name: Human Microbiology
description:
Biology of microorganisms that form commensal, mutualistic, and pathogenic
relationships with human beings, emphasizing their phylogeny, physiology,
genetics, and ecology. Effects on human nutrition, development and physiology.
Mechanisms of pathogenesis, immune response evasion, antibiotic action, and
antibiotic resistance.

name: Deterministic Opt & Desg
description:
Operations research. Optimization techniques such as linear programming,
dynamic programming, and non-linear programming. Applications in civil
engineering disciplines, including multiple realistic constraints, through
computer-based course projects.

name: Introduction to Ecology
description: General survey of the principles of ecology.
prereq:
(BIS 002A, BIS 002B, BIS 002C); (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (MAT 016B
or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); Or the equivalent.

name: African American Music
description:
Survey of African American music, such as spirituals, blues, ragtime, jazz,
theater, gospel, R&B;, rap, and art music. Emphasis on historical and
sociocultural contexts, as well as African roots.

name: Calculus
description:
Continuation of MAT 021A. Definition of definite integral, fundamental theorem
of calculus, techniques of integration. Application to area, volume, arc
length, average of a function, improper integral, surface of revolution. May
be taught abroad.
prereq: (MAT 021A C- or better or MAT 021AH C- or better) or MAT 017A B or better

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Software Engineering
description: Special topic in Software Engineering

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Primary Care Clinics
description:
Students must apply and interview with the Board of Clinica Tepati or Imani
Clinic. Field experience introduces students to health care delivery, patient
histories and physical examinations, health promotions and disease prevention,
diagnosis and treatment of episodic, acute and chronic illness, basic
laboratory testing and appropriate referral and follow-up.
prereq:
Consent of Instructor. Enrollment at the UC Davis campus; upper division
standing.

name: EM Clin Res Intern
description:
Intended to give the upper division undergraduate student an opportunity to
conduct "hands-on" clinical research in the Emergency Department. Through the
lecture/discussion, students learn the basics of conducting and developing
clinical research studies.
prereq:
Consent of Instructor. Undergraduate student in good academic standing at UC
Davis.

name: Comp Vert Organology
description:
Functional anatomy of major organ systems in vertebrates. Each system examined
from cellular to gross level in fish, birds, and mammals. Emphasis on how
differentiated cell types are integrated into tissues and organs to perform
diverse physiological functions.

name: Intro Abstract Math
description:
Rigorous treatment of mathematical concepts with emphasis on developing the
ability to understand abstract mathematical ideas, to read and write
mathematical concepts, and to prove theorems. Designed to serve as preparation
for the more rigorous upper division courses.

name: Afro-Cuban Ensemble
description:
Performance of African derived folkloric music of Cuba. Basic instrumental
technique and repertory. Focus on percussion and song traditions from Havana,
Matazas and Santiago, Cuba.

name: Parallel Architectures
description:
Techniques for software development using the shared-memory and message-
passing paradigms, on parallel architectures and networks of workstations.
Locks, barriers, and other techniques for synchronization. Introduction to
parallel algorithms.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Chamber Singers
description: Rehearsal and performance of works for small choral group.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Numerical Analysis
description:
Error analysis, approximation, interpolation, numerical differentiation and
integration. Programming in language such as Pascal, Fortran, or BASIC
required.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Precalculus
description:
Topics selected for their use in calculus, including functions and their
graphs, slope, zeroes of polynomials, exponential, logarithmic and
trigonometric functions, sketching surfaces and solids.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry; and
obtaining required score on the Precalculus Diagnostic Examination.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intro Linguistics
description: Introduction to the study of language; its nature, diversity, and structure.

name: Adv LA Studio I
description:
Landscape architecture studio featuring advanced studies and applications of
creative work, design, technology and/or theory. One day-long field trip
required.

name: Directed Gp Study
description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: East Asian Civ
description:
Surveys traditional Chinese civilization and its modern transformation.
Emphasis is on thought and religion, political and social life, art and
literature. Perspectives on contemporary China are provided.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Food & History
description:
Survey of the ways humans have fed themselves from the dawn of humanity to the
present. Transformation of plants and animals into food, cooking into cuisine,
and ceremony into etiquette.

name: Engr Graphics in Design
description:
Engineering design, descriptive geometry, pictorial sketching, computer-aided
graphics, and their application in the solution of engineering problems.

name: Directed Gp Study
description: Primarily for lower division students.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Calculus
description:
Functions, limits, continuity. Slope and derivative. Differentiation of
algebraic and transcendental functions. Applications to motion, natural
growth, graphing, extrema of a function. Differentials. L'Hopital's rule.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Linear Algebra Comp Lab
description: Introduction to MATLAB and its use in linear algebra.
prereq: MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C or MAT 021CH

name: Intro Music History
description:
History of music from the late Baroque to Beethoven. Intended primarily for
majors in music.
prereq: MUS 006A { can be concurrent }; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Creat Writ: Fiction
description: Writing of fiction. No final examination.
prereq: ENL 005F or ENL 005P; ENL 005NF; and Consent of Instructor.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Topics in Literature
description:
Intensive examination of literature considered in topical terms, not
necessarily historically. May be taught abroad.
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y

name: Envir Hort/Urban Forest
description:
Introduction to the use of plants to enhance the physical, visual and social
environment, the use of ecological principles in developing sustainable, low
maintenance landscape systems, and the career opportunities in these areas.

name: Smart Materials
description:
Electronic, optical, and magnetic properties of materials as related to
structure and processing of solid state materials. Physical principles for
understanding the properties of metals, semiconductors, ceramics, and
amorphous solids and the applications of these materials in engineering.
prereq: CHE 110A or PHY 009D; ENG 006 or ECM 006 or equivalent recommended.

name: German Lit: 800-1800
description:
German literature from the Middle Ages to Classicism (800-1800) with an
overview of major movements and authors.

name: Eur Intell 1800-70
description:
European thought in the early industrial era. Shifting cultural frameworks,
from romanticism to scientism; liberal and socialist reactions to social
change. Focus on the work of Goethe, Hegel, J.S. Mill, Marx, Darwin and
Flaubert.

name: Special Topics
description:
Study of special topics and themes in Italian literature, such as comic
literature, epic poetry, pre-20th-century theater, fascism, futurism, women
and literature, and the image of America, etc.
prereq: ITA 009 or ITA 009S; or Consent of Instructor.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Crime and Punishment
description:
Deviance and crime in early modern Europe, contrasting imaginary crimes, e.g.
witchcraft, with "real" crimes such as highway robbery and infanticide.
Examines impact of gender, sexual orientation, ethnicity, and class in
processes of criminalization.

name: Teaching in Sci & Math
description:
Exploration of effective teaching practices based on examination of how middle
school students learn math and science. Selected readings, discussion and
field experience in middle school classrooms.
prereq:
Consent of Instructor. Major in mathematics, science, or engineering; or
completion of a one-year sequence of science or calculus.

name: Diversity in K-12
description:
Analysis of research on learning styles among culturally diverse students with
review and evaluation of responsive curricula and classroom teaching
techniques. The ethnographic interview as a research tool.

name: Popn & Quant Genetics
description:
Evolution as caused by random mating, genetic drift, natural selection,
inbreeding, migration,and mutation in theory and actuality. The resemblance
between relatives and consequences of selection for quantitative traits.
Application of these ideas to topics such as the evolution of sex.

name: Sex in Nature
description:
Explores the diversity, mechanisms and evolution of sexual behaviors across
the kingdoms of life.

name: Intro Environ Design
description:
Introduction to the role of design professionals in contributing to the built
environment at a range of scales. Introduction to basic methods used by design
professionals to evaluate, design, plan, and manage landscapes and the built
environment.

name: Intro to Comp Arch
description:
Introduces basic aspects of computer architecture, including computer
performance measurement, instruction set design, computer arithmetic,
pipelined/non-pipelined implementation, and memory hierarchies (cache and
virtual memory). Presents a simplified Reduced Instruction Set Computer using
logic design methods from the prerequisite course.

name: Elementary Greek
description:
Introduction to the basic grammar and vocabulary of Classical and New
Testament Greek. Development of translation skills with emphasis on Greek-
English.

name: University Jazz Band
description:
Open to students in any major. rehearsal, study, and performance of jazz band
music and full variety of jazz band style, including swing, be-bob, and
contemporary jazz styles.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Intro to GIS
description:
Basic concepts, principles, and methods of GIS are presented. Data structures,
database design, GIS data creation, GPS, and spatial analysis. May be taught
abroad.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Directed Gp Study
description: Primarily for lower division students.

name: Earthquakes & Hazards
description:
Impact of earthquakes, tsunami, volcanoes, landslides, and floods on humans,
structures, and the environment. Discussion of the causes and effects of
disasters and catastrophes, and on prediction, preparation, and mitigation of
natural hazards.

name: Real Analysis
description:
Functions, limits of functions, continuity and uniform continuity, sequences
of functions, series of real numbers, series of functions, power series.

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Introduction to differential calculus via applications in biology and
medicine. Limits, derivatives of polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential
functions, graphing, applications of the derivative to biology and medicine.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Mech of Materials
description:
Uniaxial loading and deformation. General concepts of stress-strain-
temperature relations and yield criteria. Torsion of shafts. Bending of beams.
Deflections due to bending. Introduction to stability and buckling.
prereq: ENG 035 C- or better; MAT 022B C- or better

name: Lab: Early Childhood
description:
Application of theories of learning and development to interaction with
infants, toddlers, and preschoolers at Early Childhood Laboratory. Applied
skills in communication, guidance and curriculum.
prereq:
HDE 140 { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor. HDE 140 must be
taken concurrently for first 3 units of credit; students must contact the
Center for Child & Family Studies to enroll.

name: Medieval India
description:
Survey of history of India in the millennium preceding arrival of British in
the 18th century, focusing on interaction of the civilizations of Hinduism and
Islam and on the changing nature of the state.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Introduction to differential calculus via applications in biology and
medicine. Limits, derivatives of polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential
functions, graphing, applications of the derivative to biology and medicine.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Cardio-Respir-Renal
description:
Intense and advanced presentation of concepts in cardiovascular, respiratory,
and renal physiology including discussion of acid-base balance.
prereq: (NPB 110C or NPB 101); CHE 008B, PHY 007B and PHY 007C recommended.

name: VLSI Design
description:
CMOS devices, layout, circuits, and functional units; VLSI fabrication and
design methodologies.

name: Molec Biol & Biochem Lab
description:
Introduction to laboratory methods and procedures employed in studying
molecular biology and biochemical processes. Designed for students who need
experience in use of molecular biology and biochemical techniques as research
and analytical tools.
prereq: BIS 102; or Consent of Instructor. Must be taken concurrently with MCB 120.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Vector Analysis
description:
Continuation of MAT 021C. Definite integrals over plane and solid regions in
various coordinate systems. Line and surface integrals. Green's theorem,
Stoke's theorem, divergence theorem.
prereq: (MAT 021C C- or better or MAT 021CH C- or better) or MAT 017C B or better

name: French Phonetics
description:
Introduction to the sound-inventory of French and practice in phonetic
transcription, with a focus on ways in which phonetic contrasts signal
grammatical contrasts; spoken forms and spelling; formal differences between
the "Standard" and other varieties across the French-speaking world.

name: Stdnt-Athlete Lifeskills
description:
For intercollegiate student-athletes. Balancing academic and athletic demands.
Academic, psychological, and sociocultural issues which influence success as a
college student-athlete.

name: Smart Materials Lab
description:
Experimental investigation of electronic, optical and magnetic properties of
engineering materials, emphasizing the fundamental relationship between
microstructure and properties as well as the influence of rate processes on
the evolution of the microstructure and properties.
prereq: EMS 172 { can be concurrent }; Concurrent enrollment recommended.

name: Public Lands Mgmt
description:
Investigation of alternative approaches to public lands management by Federal
and state agencies. The role each agency's legislation plays in determining
the range of resource allocations.

name: Text Chem Analy Lab
description:
Laboratory methods and procedures employed in qualitative and quantitative
analysis of textile fibers and auxiliaries.

name: Machine Learning
description:
Introduction to machine learning. Supervised and unsupervised learning,
including classification, dimensionality reduction, regression and clustering
using modern machine learning methods. Applications of machine learning to
other fields.

name: Intro to Middle East
description:
Survey of the major social, economic, political and cultural transformations
in the Middle East from the rise of Islam (c.600A.D.) to the present,
emphasizing themes in religion and culture, politics and society.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Food Processing Lab
description:
Laboratory exercises to gain experience with common food processing operations
at the bench and pilot plant scales.

name: Geotech Earthquake Engr
description:
Tectonics, faults, site response, and probabilistic ground motion prediction
equations. Cyclic loading and liquefaction of soil elements and layers.
Empirical procedures and field tests for evaluation of triggering and
consequences, of liquefaction.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Solid Earth Geophysics
description:
Theory and use of physics in the study of the solid earth. Gravity, magnetism,
paleomagnetism, and heat flow. Application to the interpretation of the
regional and large-scale structure of the earth and to plate tectonics.
Offered irregularly.
prereq: MAT 021C; (PHY 007C or PHY 009C); Consent of Instructor.

name: Toxic Risk Assessment
description:
Current practices of health risk assessment of environmental chemicals using
toxicological principles and their application to regulatory control of these
chemicals.

name: Elem Human Physiology
description:
Introduction to physiology for non-science majors. Includes basic cell
physiology and survey of major organ systems and how they function in
homeostasis and human health.

name: Trees of Urban Forest
description:
Identification and evaluation of 200 tree species of the urban forest on
campus, in the Arboretum, and in the city of Davis; appraised and aesthetic
values, condition, and branch structure; contribution of trees to this
ecosystem. Bicycle required.

name: Keyboard Competence
description:
Training to meet the minimum piano requirements for the major in music. Scales
and simple harmonic progressions in twelve keys, both major and minor.
prereq:
MUS 006A { can be concurrent }; MUS 016A { can be concurrent }; Consent of
Instructor. MUS 006A and MUS 016A required concurrently.

name: Mktg for Tech Enterprise
description:
Quantitative analysis of needs in a product (technology-based) economy, with
emphasis on how scientists, engineers, and business people interact to develop
and market products and services.

name: Mechanisms of Cell Div
description:
The molecules and mechanisms that allow eukaryotic cells to coordinate cell
growth, DNA replication, segregation of chromosomes and cell division.

name: Public Finance
description:
Economic burden of taxation; equity and efficiency considerations in tax
design; structure and economic effects of the U.S. tax system (including
personal income tax, corporation income tax, and property tax); tax loopholes;
recent developments; tax reform proposals.

name: Earth Materials Intro
description:
Physical and chemical properties of rocks, minerals and other earth materials;
structure and composition of rock-forming minerals; formation of minerals by
precipitation from silicate liquids and aqueous fluids and by solid state
transformations.
prereq: CHE 002A; (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (GEL 001 or GEL 050, GEL 050L)

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Probabilistic Analysis
description:
Probabilistic and statistical analysis of electrical and computer systems.
Discrete and continuous random variables, expectation and moments.
Transformation of random variables. Joint and conditional densities. Limit
theorems and statistics. Noise models, system reliability and testing.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Comp Aid Mech Design
description:
Principles of computer-aided mechanism design. Computer-aided kinematic,
static, and dynamic analysis and design of planar mechanisms such as multiple-
loop linkages and geared linkages. Introduction to kinematic synthesis of
mechanisms.
prereq:
ENG 102 C- or better; (EME 005 C- or better or ENG 006 C- or better or ECS 030
C- or better)

name: PE Internship
description:
Work experience in the application of physical activity programs to teaching,
recreational, clinical or research situations under department faculty
supervision.
prereq:
Upper division standing and consent of instructor; enrollment dependent on
availability of intern positions, with priority given to Exercise Science
majors.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intro to Programming
description:
Introduction to programming and problem solving in Python. Aimed primarily at
non-major students.

name: Auto Control of Engr Sys
description:
Classical feedback control systems; block diagrams; performance
specifications; steady state errors; rise and settling times; root locus; PID
controllers; Bode and Nyquist plots; stability; phase and gain margins;
advanced topics as time allows.
prereq: ENG 100 C- or better; ENG 102 C- or better

name: Human Brain & Disease
description:
Normal function and diseases of the human brain and nervous system. Diseases
discussed include Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, leprosy, amnesia and
schizophrenia. Intended for non-science majors.

name: Research Discussion
description:
Course helps prevent or solve problems during the students research activity.
Independent advising and assistance on research proposal.
prereq:
GDB 090; GDB 187; SAS 013; GDB 189 { can be concurrent }; GBD 189 required
concurrently.

name: Global Humanities
description:
Introduction to humanities topics and methodologies; analysis of major
figures, works, and genres in world arts and literatures, with emphasis on
relationships between history, society, and culture.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Topics In Economics
description: Selected topics in economic analysis and public policy. Variable content.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Elementary Hindi/Urdu I
description:
Introduction to Devanagari Script through development of all language skills
in a cultural context with emphasis on communicative proficiency.

name: Paleobiology
description:
Evolution and ecological structure of the biosphere from the origin of life to
the present.

name: Elementary French
description: Continuation of course 2.

name: Short Calculus
description:
Limits; differentiation of algebraic functions; analytic geometry;
applications, in particular to maxima and minima problems.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Tutoring in CS
description: Tutoring in computer science courses, especially introductory courses.

name: Adulthood & Aging
description:
Development during early, middle, and late adulthood; biological, cognitive,
and psycho-social aspects of adult development. Emphasis on normative patterns
of development which characterize "successful aging."

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Diversity in K-12
description:
Analysis of research on learning styles among culturally diverse students with
review and evaluation of responsive curricula and classroom teaching
techniques. The ethnographic interview as a research tool.

name: Theory of Reference
description:
Survey of issues and views concerning reference, or how words refer to things.
Topics include names and descriptions, the distinction between sense and
reference, the puzzle of non-referring terms, causal theories of reference,
and possibility and necessity.
prereq: One course in Philosophy or Linguistics recommended.

name: Elementary Italian
description:
Introduction to Italian grammar and development of all language skills in a
cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

name: College Writing-SCC157E
description: Not available.

name: Writing in Science
description:
Writing abstracts, research proposals, scientific papers, other forms of
scientific communication. Presenting data graphically. Primarily for students
engaged in or planning careers in basic or applied research.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing or enrollment in a graduate science curriculum.

name: Writ in Intl Relations
description: Advanced instruction in writing in international relations.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Intro To Fem Theory
description:
Introduction to the emergence of feminist theory and to key concepts in
feminist theorizing. Examination of past and current debates over sexuality,
race, identity politics, and the social construction of womens experience.
prereq: WMS 050 recommended or consent of instructor.

name: Advanced Operations
description:
Military small unit tactical theory as the basis for leadership development.
Principles of war, contemporary operating environment, Geneva Law of Land
Warfare, military offensive and defensive operations. Emphasis on development
of critical thinking, problem solving, and communication skills.
prereq: MSC 131; or Consent of Instructor. Upper division standing.

name: Cell Reg/Nutrient Metab
description:
Cellular regulation from nutritional/toxicological perspective. Emphasis: role
of biofactors on modulation of signal transduction pathways, role of specific
organelles in organization/regulation of metabolic transformations, major
cofactor functions, principles of pharmacology/toxicology important to
understanding nutrient/toxicant metabolism.

name: Calculus
description:
Functions, limits, continuity. Slope and derivative. Differentiation of
algebraic and transcendental functions. Applications to motion, natural
growth, graphing, extrema of a function. Differentials. L'Hopital's rule.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Field Exp In P E
description:
Tutoring or teachers aide in physical education activities, including athletic
coaching, in public schools under the guidance of a regular teacher with
supervision by a departmental faculty person.
prereq: PHE 001 or PHE 007; Upper division standing.

name: Classical Physics
description:
Continuation of PHY 009A. Fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, wave phenomena,
optics.
prereq: PHY 009A; MAT 021C; MAT 021D { can be concurrent }

name: Dynamics
description:
Kinematics and kinetics of particles, systems of particles, and of rigid
bodies; application of these topics are applied to engineering problems.
prereq: ENG 035 C- or better; MAT 022B C- or better

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Vector Analysis
description:
Continuation of MAT 021C. Definite integrals over plane and solid regions in
various coordinate systems. Line and surface integrals. Green's theorem,
Stoke's theorem, divergence theorem.
prereq: (MAT 021C C- or better or MAT 021CH C- or better) or MAT 017C B or better

name: Classical Physics
description:
Continuation of PHY 009A. Fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, wave phenomena,
optics.
prereq: PHY 009A; MAT 021C; MAT 021D { can be concurrent }

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Physical Geology
description:
The Earth, its materials, its internal and external processes, its development
through time by sea-floor spreading and global plate tectonics.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Lab Biol Cons Fishes
description:
Morphology, taxonomy, conservation, and identification of marine and
freshwater fishes with emphasis on California species.
prereq: WFC 120 { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor.

name: Abnormal Psych
description:
Descriptive and functional account of behavioral disorders, with primary
consideration given to neurotic and psychotic behavior.

name: Young Children
description:
Integration of research, theory and practice in child development, emphasizing
the role of relationships in creating a growth-promoting environment for young
children. Includes: peer relationships, emotional understanding and self
regulation, attachment, communication and school readiness.
prereq:
HDE 100A; HDE 140L { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor. HDE 140L
required concurrently.

name: Env Chng Dis & Pub Hlth
description:
Analysis of environmental changes from pre-history to the present and their
influence on disease distribution, virulence and public health. Focus on
critical study of many human-driven environmental changes and the accelerated
transformation/spread of pathogens under globalization.

name: Intro To Literature
description:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both
analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English
prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Elementary Latin
description:
Introduction to basic grammar and vocabulary and development of translation
skills with emphasis on Latin to English.

name: Advanced Composition
description:
Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within
and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique. May be taught abroad.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM
001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C-
or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: ICA Sports Program
description:
Sport specific advanced comprehensive training, instruction, and practice for
the highly skilled collegiate varsity athlete. Development and improvement of
performance skills utilizing motor-learning, nutritional science, and
motivational theory. Classes offered in all UC Davis intercollegiate athletic
sports.

name: Cognitive Development
description:
Theories, methods, evidence, and debates in the field of cognitive
development, such as nature/nurture, constraints on learning, and the role of
plasticity. Topics include attention, memory, concepts about the physical and
social world, and language.

name: Agriculture & Society
description:
Development of agriculture as a major enterprise in modern society with the
concomitant reduction in the labor force and family farms. Analysis of issues
including mechanization, migrant labor, corporate farming, and public resource
policy.

name: Topics In Economics
description: Selected topics in economic analysis and public policy. Variable content.

name: Lit in English I
description:
Historical introduction to English language and literature from 800-1700.
Linguistic borrowing, innovation, and change. Emergence of key literary
genres. Colonial America as a new site of English literary production and
consumption.
prereq: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; Or equivalent.

name: Comp In French
description:
Instruction and practice in expository writing in French, with emphasis on
organization, correct syntax, and vocabulary building.

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Introduction to differential calculus via applications in biology and
medicine. Limits, derivatives of polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential
functions, graphing, applications of the derivative to biology and medicine.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Intro Multiling Writing
description:
Reading and writing paragraphs and short multi-paragraph texts for academic
purposes. Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Intro Multiling Writing
description:
Reading and writing paragraphs and short multi-paragraph texts for academic
purposes. Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Macromolec Struct Funct
description:
An in-depth investigation into protein and nucleic acid structure and
thermodynamics and how these properties influence their biological functions.
Key examples of important functional classes of these molecules will be
examined.

name: Animal Behavior
description:
Basic principles of behavioral organization in vertebrate and invertebrate
animals. Underlying physiological and ethological mechanisms. The evolution of
behavior, with special emphasis on behavior under natural conditions.

name: Food Chem Clin Nutr
description:
Chemical and physical principles that influence functional properties,
nutrient content, safety, and sensory aspects of food. Emphasis on the
application of these concepts in clinical nutrition.
prereq:
CHE 008B C or better or CHE 118C C or better or CHE 128C C or better;
Concurrent with FST 100A recommended.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Elementary Italian
description:
Introduction to Italian grammar and development of all language skills in a
cultural context with special emphasis on communication. May be taught abroad.

name: Early Lit In Engl
description:
Study of early Japanese literature from the Nara to the end of the Heian
period through a broad survey of the major literary genres such as lyric
poetry, court diaries, prose narratives, poem-tales, and classical Chinese
writings.

name: Neurobiol Addict Drugs
description:
Neurobiological basis for the effects and mechanisms of action of drugs with
addictive potential, including opiates (morphine, heroin, methadone),
amphetamines, cocaine, nicotine, marijuana (cannabinoids), alcohol, caffeine,
and mind-altering drugs such as LSD and antidepressants.
prereq: NPB 100 or NPB 110B or NPB 110C or NPB 101; Or equivalents.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Elementary Spanish
description:
Continuation of course 1, 1S, or previous high school experience in the areas
of grammar and basic language skills. Online format combining synchronous
chatting with technologically based materials.
prereq: SPA 001 or SPA 001S; Or the equivalent.

name: Intermed Soc Stat
description:
Intermediate level course in statistical analysis of social data, emphasizing
the logic and use of statistical measures, procedures, and mathematical models
especially relevant to sociological analysis.

name: Intro to ECE
description:
Electrical & Computer Engineering as a professional activity. What Electrical
& Computer Engineers know and how they use their knowledge.

name: Mechanical Design
description:
Principles of mechanics applied to design. Deformation and stress analysis.
Structural integrity under static and fluctuating loads. Projects demonstrate
progression from concept to engineering analysis, with emphasis on strength
and durability.
prereq:
(ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better); (ENG 104 C- or better, EME
050 C- or better { can be concurrent })

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Signal Analy & Comm
description:
Signal analysis based on Fourier methods. Fourier series and transforms; time-
sampling, convolution, and filtering; spectral density; modulation: carrier-
amplitude, carrier-frequency, and pulse-amplitude.

name: Financing New Bus Vtrs
description:
Concepts/methods used to structure and finance new business ventures. Topics
include evaluating the net social (financial) benefit of new investment
projects; raising venture capital; the role of the venture capitalist; and the
choice of organizational structure in new ventures.
prereq: MGT 011A; (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); STA 013

name: Intro To Philos
description:
Problems of philosophy through major writings from various periods. Problems
are drawn from political, aesthetic, religious, metaphysical, and
epistemological concerns of philosophy.

name: Elementary Japanese
description:
Introduction to spoken and written Japanese in cultural contexts, with
emphasis on communication.

name: Intro Microbiology
description:
Essentials of microbial biology, emphasizing phylogeny, physiology, genetics,
ecology, and pathogenesis. Interactions with other microbes, humans, and the
biosphere. Uses of microbes in agriculture and biotechnology. May be taught
abroad.
prereq: (BIS 001A or BIS 002A); CHE 002B { can be concurrent }

name: Stat Data Technologies
description:
Essentials of using relational databases and SQL. Processing data in blocks.
Scraping Web pages and using Web services/APIs. Basics of text mining.
Interactive data visualization with Web technologies. Computational data
workflow and best practices. Statistical methods.

name: Primary Care Clinics
description:
Students must apply and interview with the Board of Clinica Tepati or Imani
Clinic. Field experience exposes lower division students to health care
delivery, patient histories, physical examinations,health promotion, disease
prevention, diagnosis; treatment of episodic,acute,chronic illness;
appropriate referral and follow-up.
prereq:
Consent of Instructor. Enrollment at the UC Davis campus, for freshman and
sophomore students.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Business Writing
description:
Effective communication in and for organizations, including businesses
(corporations), government agencies, and non-profit organizations. Suitable
for students entering careers that require substantial communications, such as
management, public relations, and grant writing.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Special Study
description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: The Chinese Revolution
description:
Analysis of China's cultural and political transformation from Confucian
empire into Communist state. Emphasis on emergence and triumph of peasant
revolutionary strategy (to 1949), with some attention to its implications for
post-revolutionary culture and politics.

name: New Food Product Ideas
description:
Create, refine, test and present viable ideas for new food products.
Activities include trend monitoring, consumer research, idea generation,
concept screening, and new product concept presentations.
prereq: FST 050; BIS 002A; PHY 007A; PHY 007B; PHY 007C; CHE 002A; CHE 002B; CHE 002C

name: Elementary French
description: Continuation of course 1.

name: Linear Algebra
description:
Matrices and linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues, eigenvectors,
diagonalization, factorization.
prereq:
(MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 017C C- or better or MAT 021C C- or better or
MAT 021CH C- or better); (ENG 006 or EME 005 or ECH 060 or MAT 022AL { can be
concurrent })

name: College Writing-SCC157E
description: Not available.

name: Intro Abstract Math
description:
Rigorous treatment of mathematical concepts with emphasis on developing the
ability to understand abstract mathematical ideas, to read and write
mathematical concepts, and to prove theorems. Designed to serve as preparation
for the more rigorous upper division courses.

name: Mathematics & Computers
description:
Introduction to computational mathematics, symbolic computation, and computer
generated/verified proofs in algebra, analysis and geometry. Investigation of
rigorous new mathematics developed in conjunction with modern computational
questions and the role that computers play in mathematical conjecture and
experimentation.
prereq: MAT 022A or MAT 067; (MAT 025 or MAT 108 or MAT 114 or MAT 115A or MAT 145)

name: Intro to Engr Design
description:
Introduction to the engineering design process that incorporates the
development of oral and written communication skills integral to the design
process. Conducted in workshop format with hands-on engagement in the design
process.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Group Study
description: Directed group study.

name: Primary Care Clinics
description:
Students must apply and interview with the Board of Clinica Tepati or Imani
Clinic. Field experience introduces students to health care delivery, patient
histories and physical examinations, health promotions and disease prevention,
diagnosis and treatment of episodic, acute and chronic illness, basic
laboratory testing and appropriate referral and follow-up.
prereq:
Consent of Instructor. Enrollment at the UC Davis campus; upper division
standing.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Computers in Education
description:
Applications of computers in education as instructional, intellectual, and
communication tools.

name: Writing: Poetry
description:
Elementary principles of writing poetry. Write both in prescribed forms and in
experimental forms of their own choosing. No final examination.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Evolution: Sci & Wrld Vw
description:
Introduction to biological evolution. Emphasis on historical development,
major lines of evidence and causes of evolution; relationships between
evolution and Earth history; the impact of evolutionary thought on other
disciplines.

name: Mexican Politics
description:
Introduction to the politics of contemporary Mexico. Focus on rise, fall, and
aftermath of Mexico's one-party dominant system.

name: Preparatory Chem-SCC110C
description: Not available.

name: Circuits II
description:
Theory, application, and design of analog circuits. Methods of analysis
including frequency response, SPICE simulation, and Laplace transform.
Operational amplifiers and design of active filters.

name: ICA Sports Program
description:
Sport specific advanced comprehensive training, instruction, and practice for
the highly skilled collegiate varsity athlete. Development and improvement of
performance skills utilizing motor-learning, nutritional science, and
motivational theory. Classes offered in all UC Davis intercollegiate athletic
sports.

name: Tutoring in Microbiology
description:
Assisting the instructor in one of the section's regular courses by tutoring
individual or small groups of students in a laboratory, in voluntary
discussion groups, or other voluntary course activities.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Upper division standing.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Analysis of Econ Data
description:
Analysis of economic data to investigate key relationships emphasized in
introductory micro and macro economics. Obtaining, transforming, displaying
data; statistical analysis of economic data; basic univariate and multivariate
regression analysis.
prereq:
(ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B; (STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 032); (MAT 016A
or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); or Consent of
Instructor.

name: Advanced Composition
description:
Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within
and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique. May be taught abroad.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM
001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C-
or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Intro to Math Statistics
description:
Testing theory, tools and applications from probability theory, Linear model
theory, ANOVA, goodness-of-fit.

name: Writing in Health Prof
description:
Advanced expository writing common in the health professions, emphasizing
effective communication between the writer and different audiences. Topics
relate to health, disability, and disease. Suitable for students planning
careers in professions such as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy,
optometry.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Tactical Leadership
description:
Small unit tactical operations serve as the basis for enhancement of
leadership performance through tactical application. Assessment of leadership
attributes, skills, and actions through participation in a variety of
leadership roles in problem-solving exercises.
prereq: MSC 131; or Consent of Instructor. Upper division standing.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Principles Soil Sci
description:
Soil as part of natural and managed ecosystems and landscapes. Solid, liquid,
and gas phases and their interactions in the soil. Water, gas and heat
movement in soil. Soil biology. Plant nutrient acquisition and use.Soil
development, management and use.
prereq:
College-level courses in each of chemistry, physics, biology, and geology
recommended.

name: Process Geomorphology
description:
Quantitative description and interpretation of landscapes with emphasis on the
relationships between physical processes, mass conservation, and landform
evolution. Topics covered include physical and chemical weathering,
hillslopes, debris flows, fluvial systems, alluvial fans, pedogenesis, eolian
transport, glaciation and Quaternary geochronology.

name: Black Hist In Amer
description:
History of black people and race relations from 1860-present. Emphasis on
Civil War, Reconstruction, Segregation, Age of Accommodation, black
nationalism, urbanization, civil rights, and changing ideology of race
relations.

name: Theory of Knowledge
description:
Analysis of the concept of knowledge. The relation between knowledge, belief
and truth. Development of foundationalist, coherentist and externalist
theories of justified belief. Examination of skepticism.

name: Partial Diff Equations
description:
Derivation of partial differential equations; separation of variables;
equilibrium solutions and Laplace's equation; Fourier series; method of
characteristics for the one dimensional wave equation. Solution of
nonhomogeneous equations.

name: Topics In Economics
description: Selected topics in economic analysis and public policy. Variable content.

name: Computational Linguistic
description:
Understanding the nature of language through computer modeling of linguistic
abilities. Relationships between human cognition and computer representations
of cognitive processing.

name: Lang Dev Chicano Child
description:
Bilingualism, first and second language acquisition, bilingual education,
language assessment, Chicano Spanish and the role of dialect varieties in the
classroom.

name: Malting & Brewing Sci
description:
Technology of the malting, brewing and fermentation processes is integrated
with the chemistry, biochemistry and microbiology that determine industrial
practices and product quality.
prereq: (BIS 102, BIS 103) or BIS 105; senior standing recommended.

name: Longevity
description:
Nature, origin, determinants, and limits of longevity with particular
reference to humans; emphasis on implications of findings from non-human model
systems including natural history, ecology and evolution of life span;
description of basic demographic techniques including life table methods.
prereq: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Intro to Symbol Logic
description:
Syntax and semantics of the symbolic language sentence logic. Symbols of
sentence logic. Translation between sentence logic and English. Truth table
interpretation of sentence logic. Proof techniques. Application of truth
tables and proof techniques to arguments in English.

name: Heat Transfer
description:
Conduction, convection, and radiation heat transfer. Computational modeling of
heat transfer in engineering. Applications to engineering equipment with the
use of digital computers.
prereq:
(ENG 006 C- or better or EME 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better); ENG
103 C- or better; ENG 105 C- or better

name: Numerical Analysis
description:
Error analysis, approximation, interpolation, numerical differentiation and
integration. Programming in language such as Pascal, Fortran, or BASIC
required.

name: American Humanities
description:
Introduction to humanities topics and methodologies; analysis of major
figures, works, and genres in American arts and literatures, with emphasis on
relationships between history, society, and culture.

name: Europe Thought 1400-1800
description:
History of European thought on politics, society, science, and religion from
1400 to 1800. Cultural impact of printing press, Protestant Reformation, wars,
exploration, and empire.

name: Short Calculus
description:
Differential equations; partial derivatives; double integrals; applications;
series.
prereq:
MAT 016B C- or better or MAT 017B C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better or MAT
021BH C- or better

name: Business Writing
description:
Effective communication in and for organizations, including businesses
(corporations), government agencies, and non-profit organizations. Suitable
for students entering careers that require substantial communications, such as
management, public relations, and grant writing.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Curr Topics in Nutrition
description:
Exploration of current applications and controversies in nutrition. Rread
scientific journal articles and write summaries, as well as give brief oral
presentations. Topics change to reflect current interests and issues.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Intro to Engineering
description:
Introduction to the role of engineers in the acquisition and development of
engineering knowledge, the differences and similarities among engineering
fields, and the work ethic and skills required for engineering.

name: Spec Top:Spanish Cul/Lit
description:
Special topics in the study of Spanish literature and culture. May be taught
abroad.
prereq: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S

name: Advanced Composition
description:
Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within
and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique. May be taught abroad.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM
001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C-
or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Writing in Health Prof
description:
